entries.title: The Verse of Purification (Ayat al-Tathir)

verses.context: Allah removes all impurity from the Ahl al-Bayt and purifies them completely

entries.revelationContext: Revealed when the Prophet gathered Fatimah, Ali, Hasan, and Husayn under his cloak (Hadith al-Kisa) and declared them as his Ahl al-Bayt, excluding his wives from this designation according to numerous Shia and Sunni narrations.
entries.shiaPerspective: This verse establishes the absolute purity and infallibility of the five members of the household. The masculine plural pronoun ('ankum' - from you) indicates this verse is specifically for the Prophet's family, not his wives as the preceding verses use feminine pronouns.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: Following the pure guidance of Ahl al-Bayt ensures we stay on the straight path, free from spiritual and moral impurity in our modern lives.

entries.title: The Verse of Love (Mawadda fil-Qurba)

verses.context: The Prophet asks for no reward except love for his close family

entries.revelationContext: When asked what reward he sought for his prophetic mission, this verse was revealed making love for the Prophet's family the only compensation believers should offer.
entries.shiaPerspective: The 'qurba' (close relatives) refers specifically to Ahl al-Bayt. Loving them is not optional but an obligation for every Muslim, as it is the only 'wage' the Prophet requested for bringing Islam. This love must be demonstrated through following their guidance.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: True love for Ahl al-Bayt means following their teachings, upholding justice as they did, and defending the oppressed in our communities today.

entries.title: The Verse of Mubahala (Mutual Invocation)

verses.context: Allah commands the Prophet to bring his family for mutual invocation against the Christians of Najran

entries.revelationContext: When Christians of Najran disputed with the Prophet about Jesus, Allah commanded both parties to invoke divine curse upon the liars. The Prophet brought Ali (as 'ourselves'), Fatimah (as 'our women'), and Hasan and Husayn (as 'our sons'), demonstrating their supreme spiritual station.
entries.shiaPerspective: This verse proves Ahl al-Bayt's proximity to the Prophet and their exalted position. The Christians withdrew from the challenge upon seeing these noble souls, recognizing their divine status. 'Ourselves' indicates Ali's soul was one with the Prophet's.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: The courage to stand for truth with family, even when facing powerful opponents, reflects the spirit of Mubahala we should embody today.

entries.title: The Verse of Wilayah (Authority and Guardianship)

verses.context: True authority belongs to those who give charity while in prayer

entries.revelationContext: Revealed when Imam Ali gave his ring to a beggar while in the state of ruku' (bowing) during prayer. This verse establishes Ali's divinely appointed authority (Wilayah) after the Prophet.
entries.shiaPerspective: The verse uses present tense 'those who give' while bowing, a unique act performed by Ali. This establishes his Imamate and Wilayah over believers. The sequence of Allah, Messenger, then believers who give in prayer shows the chain of divine authority.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: True leadership combines spiritual devotion with practical service to the needy. Our leaders must exemplify both worship and social justice simultaneously.

entries.title: Feeding the Needy (Surah Al-Insan)

verses.context: They feed the needy, orphan, and captive despite their own hunger
We feed you only for Allah's sake, seeking neither reward nor thanks

entries.revelationContext: When Hasan and Husayn fell ill, their parents vowed to fast for three days if they recovered. Upon recovery, they fasted but gave away their iftar (breaking fast) food for three consecutive nights to a needy person, an orphan, and a captive, breaking their fast only with water.
entries.shiaPerspective: This entire surah was revealed in praise of Ahl al-Bayt's sacrifice and selflessness. Their preferring others despite their own hunger exemplifies the highest level of devotion and compassion, establishing the standard for Islamic charity.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: True charity means sacrificing our own needs for others. In a world of poverty and refugees, we must follow Ahl al-Bayt's example of feeding the hungry even when we ourselves are in need.

entries.title: Surah Al-Kawthar (The Abundance)

verses.context: Allah grants the Prophet abundant good through his progeny
The Prophet's enemies will be cut off, not him

entries.revelationContext: When the Prophet's sons passed away in infancy, his enemies mocked him as 'abtar' (cut off/without progeny). Allah revealed this surah declaring that abundance and continuity would come through his daughter Fatimah's lineage.
entries.shiaPerspective: Al-Kawthar refers to both the river in Paradise and the blessed lineage of the Prophet through Fatimah. All subsequent Imams descend from her, proving the Prophet's line continues forever. His enemies, not him, were truly cut off from legacy and remembrance.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: True legacy is not in wealth or numbers but in righteous offspring who carry forward divine guidance. The global reverence for Ahl al-Bayt proves Allah's promise of Kawthar.

entries.title: The Verse of Proclamation (Tabligh)

verses.context: O Messenger, proclaim what has been sent down to you, or you have not fulfilled your mission

entries.revelationContext: Revealed at Ghadir Khumm on the Prophet's final pilgrimage, commanding him to announce Ali's succession. The urgency and divine protection promised in this verse indicates the critical importance of this announcement.
entries.shiaPerspective: This verse preceded the famous declaration 'Man kuntu mawlahu fa hadha Aliyyun mawlahu' (Whoever's master I am, Ali is his master). The warning that failing to convey this would mean not completing the prophetic mission shows that Imamate is fundamental to Islam, not secondary.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: Truth must be proclaimed clearly and publicly, especially when it concerns leadership and guidance. We cannot hide divine appointments due to political pressures or fears.

entries.title: Completion of Religion (Ikmal al-Din)

verses.context: Today I have perfected your religion and completed My favor upon you

entries.revelationContext: Revealed at Ghadir Khumm immediately after the Prophet announced Ali's Wilayah. The religion was completed not just with laws and rituals, but with the establishment of divinely appointed leadership after the Prophet.
entries.shiaPerspective: The timing of this verse proves that Imamate is the completion of religion. Without the appointment of Ali and subsequent Imams as guides, Islam would be incomplete. This verse links religious perfection with the declaration of Ali's authority.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: Complete faith requires accepting all pillars of religion, including divinely appointed leadership. Half-hearted belief or selective acceptance leaves one's faith incomplete.

entries.title: The Rights of Kinfolk (Khums)

verses.context: Know that one-fifth of war gains belongs to Allah, the Messenger, and close relatives

entries.revelationContext: Establishes Khums (one-fifth) as the financial right of Ahl al-Bayt. Since they were forbidden from receiving charity (Zakat), Allah provided for them through Khums, maintaining their dignity and sustenance.
entries.shiaPerspective: The 'close relatives' (dhil-qurba) refers specifically to Ahl al-Bayt. Khums is not just a tax but acknowledgment of their special status and role in guiding the community. It ensures their independence from political powers and ability to serve Islam freely.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: Supporting religious scholars and the progeny of the Prophet through Khums enables them to dedicate themselves to preserving and teaching Islam without compromise.

entries.title: Giving to Relatives (Dhil-Qurba)

verses.context: Give close relatives their due rights

entries.revelationContext: Commands believers to give the Prophet's family their due rights, both material (through Khums) and spiritual (through respect, love, and following their guidance).
entries.shiaPerspective: The 'due right' includes both financial support and recognizing their spiritual authority. Denying Ahl al-Bayt their rights is a grave injustice that violates this clear Quranic command.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: Honoring and supporting the righteous descendants of the Prophet is not optional sentimentality but a Quranic obligation that strengthens the Muslim community.

entries.title: Obey Those in Authority (Ulil-Amr)

verses.context: Obey Allah, the Messenger, and those in authority among you

entries.revelationContext: Establishes the chain of authority after the Prophet. 'Those in authority' (Ulil-Amr) are not elected leaders but divinely appointed Imams from Ahl al-Bayt who possess knowledge and infallibility.
entries.shiaPerspective: Absolute obedience is commanded only for those who are infallible - Allah, the Prophet, and the Imams. This verse would be impossible to follow if Ulil-Amr could err, as it places them in the same category as Allah and the Prophet regarding obedience.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: True Islamic governance requires leaders who possess divine knowledge and are free from error. Following the guidance of Ahl al-Bayt through their teachings ensures we obey the true Ulil-Amr.

entries.title: Follow Those Who Are Guided

verses.context: These are the ones Allah has guided, so follow their guidance

ahlulbaytMembers: Ahl al-Bayt as inheritors of prophetic guidance
entries.revelationContext: After mentioning previous prophets, Allah commands following their guidance. This guidance continues through Ahl al-Bayt who inherit the knowledge and spirituality of all prophets.
entries.shiaPerspective: The chain of divine guidance doesn't end with the Prophet Muhammad but continues through his purified family. They are the inheritors of all prophetic knowledge and the guides for humanity until the Day of Judgment.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: In times of confusion and conflicting opinions, returning to the authentic teachings of Ahl al-Bayt provides the clear guidance we need.

entries.title: The Household of Remembrance (Ahl al-Dhikr)

verses.context: Ask the people of knowledge if you do not know
Ask the people of remembrance if you do not know

entries.revelationContext: When questioned about religious matters, Allah directs people to 'Ahl al-Dhikr' (People of Remembrance/Knowledge). Numerous hadiths identify Ahl al-Bayt as the true Ahl al-Dhikr who possess complete knowledge of the Quran.
entries.shiaPerspective: The Dhikr (Remembrance/Quran) is with Ahl al-Bayt, making them 'Ahl al-Dhikr'. They are the authoritative interpreters of the Quran, and returning to them for understanding religion is a Quranic command, not optional.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: In an age of information overload and conflicting fatwas, referring to the authentic teachings preserved by Ahl al-Bayt's school of thought ensures correct understanding.

entries.title: Warn Your Closest Relatives
entries.revelationContext: At the feast of Dhul-Asheera, when the Prophet first publicly declared his prophethood to his clan, he also announced Ali as his successor and brother, saying 'Whoever follows me, this Ali will be my successor and inheritor.'
entries.shiaPerspective: This verse shows that from the very beginning of public preaching, the Prophet designated Ali as his successor. The linkage of warning about prophethood with announcement of succession demonstrates their inseparability.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: Truth and leadership go hand in hand. When proclaiming divine message, we must also clarify who the rightful guides are, not leaving people confused about authority.

entries.title: Examples of Righteous Women

verses.context: Allah presents the example of Pharaoh's wife who chose faith
And Mary who guarded her chastity - We breathed into her Our Spirit

entries.revelationContext: These verses present the two most exalted women before Islam as examples. The Prophet declared Fatimah as the leader of all women in Paradise, surpassing even Mary and Asiya, making her the ultimate example for believers.
entries.shiaPerspective: If Mary and Asiya are presented as supreme examples, and Fatimah is declared superior to them both ('leader of women of the worlds'), then following Fatimah's example is the highest aspiration for believers. Her spiritual rank surpasses all previous women.
entries.contemporaryRelevance: Women's empowerment in Islam means following the example of Fatimah - strong, knowledgeable, courageous in defending truth, while maintaining deep spirituality and family devotion.
